The Tonle Sap Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Project 
(the Project) will provide rural water supply and sanitation (RWSS) 
facilities to about 1,760 villages in five provinces around the Tonle 
Sap  basin.  It  will  include  community  mobilization,  sanitation  and 
hygiene education programs, and capacity building and institution 
strengthening.  The  Project  will  provide  an  estimated  1.09  million 
people  with  safe  drinking  water,  of  whom  about  0.72  million  will 
also  benefit  from  improved  sanitation  facilities.  It  has  been 
formulated  as  a  sector  project.  Subproject  selection  combines 
elements of poverty targeting with a demand-responsive approach 
to ensure the sustainability of the facilities.  
 
Cambodia  has  made  some  progress  in  providing  water  and 
sanitation services to its people, but rural water coverage remains 
the  second  lowest  in  Asia.  Providing  access  to  water  and 
sanitation is integral to the Government’s efforts to improve health 
and  living  conditions  in  Cambodia  and  meet  the  Cambodian 
Millennium  Development  Goals  (CMDGs).  The  great  majority  of 
rural  and  poor  households  still  rely  on  self-provision  through 
groundwater  abstraction,  rainwater  collection,  or  the  use  of 
surface  water,  with  little  government  investment  to  ensure 
sustainable  quantity  or  monitor  water  quality.  Sanitation  in  rural 
areas  is  almost  nonexistent  (limited  to  simple  on-site  facilities), 
and the majority of the rural population still continues to defecate 
in the open. 

Partly  due  to  the  lack  of  access  of  safe  water  and  sanitation, 
Cambodia’s infant mortality rate is the second highest in Asia and 
has increased in the past decade. Many rural areas in Cambodia 
show  high  rates  of  waterborne  and  water-related  diseases.  Poor 
people—particularly  women,  children,  and  the  elderly—suffer 
greatly  from  using  water  unfit  for  human  consumption  and  from 
poor hygiene.

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Following  a  request  from  the  Government  of  Cambodia  (the  Government),  the  Asian 
2. 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  a  small-scale  technical  assistance  (SSTA)1  in  February 
2005 to prepare the Tonle Sap Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Project. The SSTA, 
implemented by Department of Rural Water Supply in the Ministry of Rural Development (MRD), 
was built upon the previous ADB-supported project preparatory technical assistance2 completed 
in  August  2002.  The  SSTA  was  completed  on  20  May  2005.  The  Government  officially 
expressed interest in availing ADB funds for the ensuing grant.3  
 
ADB’s overarching goal for Cambodia, as defined in its CSP (2005–2009), is sustainable 
3. 
poverty  reduction.  To  achieve  this, the  CSP  focuses  on  three  strategic  pillars:  (i)  broad-based 
economic growth, (ii) inclusive social development, and (iii) good governance. The provision of 
rural  water  supply  and  sanitation  (RWSS)  facilities  is  highlighted  as  one  means  by  which 
inclusive social development can be achieved, and the RWSS sector is identified as a sector in 
which ADB will play a catalytic role. The CSP also stresses three crosscutting themes—private 
sector  development,  gender,  and  the  environment—that  help  support  poverty  reduction.  The 
Project will contribute to all of these crosscutting themes. The Tonle Sap basin is identified as 
the priority area where ADB interventions will be progressively focused. The Project will support 
the  development  of  RWSS  in  five  provinces  around  the  Tonle  Sap  basin:  Battambang, 
Kampong Chhnang, Kampong Thom, Pursat, and Siem Reap. The Project will contribute to the 
achievement  of  Cambodian  Millennium  Development  Goals  (CMDGs)4  to  provide,  by  2015, 
access to safe water to half of the rural population and access to sanitation facilities to 30%. 
 
A.

RWSS  has  been  an  integral  part  of  the  Government’s  overall  strategy  for  rural 
4. 
development and poverty reduction. The Rectangular Strategy,5 the National Poverty Reduction 
Strategy6  and  the  CMDGs  place  high  priority  on  RWSS.  Rural  households  account  for  almost 
90% of the total poor. The poverty rate in rural areas, estimated at 40.1%, is much higher than 
in  urban  areas,  where  29.7%  of  the  population  is  poor.  Under-5  child  mortality  in  the  country 
stands  at  a  high  124  per  1,000  live  births,  and  maternal  mortality  is  estimated  at  437  per 
100,000  live  births.  While  the  number  of  people  with  access  to  safe  water  and  sanitation  has 
increased since 1989, mainly as a result of external assistance, Cambodia remains the country 
with the lowest water and sanitation coverage in East Asia and one of the lowest in the world.

8. 
Most of the infrastructure provided by earlier assistance to RWSS in Cambodia suffered 
from  inadequate  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M),  which  contributed  to  the  failure  of  the 
systems  within  a  few  years.  Community  management  structures  were  not  established  in  most 
cases  and,  when  they  were,  did  not  receive  the  necessary  technical  support  and  training  to 
ensure efficient functioning. Lack of community involvement, especially of women, has been the 
main reason for poor sustainability. Communities’ lack of easy access to spare parts, especially 
for water pumps, has also been a constraint. To improve the O&M of the RWSS systems, the 
Project  will  assist  in  the  formation  and  capacity  building  of  water  and  sanitation  user  groups 
(WSUGs). National guidelines on WSUGs were drafted during project preparation. The WSUG 
guidelines state that all users must contribute to the capital and O&M costs of the systems by 
linking  the  right  to  use  the  water  with  these  financial  contributions.  The  poorest  households, 
identified and verified by the community, will be exempted from O&M cash contributions but will 
be  required  to  contribute  in-kind.  At  least  40%  of  WSUG  board  members  will  be  women,  who 
will  account  for  at  least  half  of  the  members  receiving  technical  O&M  training.  The  ethnic 
makeup of WSUG boards will reflect WSUG membership. 
 
9. 
Beneficiaries’ lack of choice on the different technological and cost options available has 
led to the construction of RWSS systems that are either inadequate or unaffordable. As a result, 
many  water  systems  have  failed.  The  NWSSP  stresses  the  importance  of  informing  the 
population, both men and women, about all feasible domestic water and sanitation choices, and 
of  providing  solutions  that  guarantee  the  availability  of  safe  water  that  suits  the  drinking, 
cooking,  and  washing  needs  of  the  population. The  improvement  of  access  to  safe  water  and 
sanitation  in  areas  where  the  quality  or  the  quantity  of  the  water  is  not  adequate  will  require 
testing  new  technologies  such  as  (i)  very  deep  tube  wells,  (ii)  treatment  of  surface  water,  (iii) 
new  methods  of  storing  and  filtering  water  in  individual  households,  and  (iv)  new  types  of 
latrines. The Project will support these innovations on a pilot basis. 
 
10. 
The participation of the Cambodian private sector in the construction and O&M of RWSS 
systems,  which  could  improve  the  sustainability  and  efficiency  of  the  RWSS  sector,  remains 
very  limited.  Although  the  number  of  private  drilling  companies  is  increasing,  their  technical 
capabilities and size are limited by the lack of training and the scarcity of affordable access to 
credit. In a few cases, community infrastructure is managed by the private sector. Although this 
solution  seems  promising  and  is  a  good  alternative  to  the  many  cases  of  failed  community 
management, little effort has been made so far to help communities and private entrepreneurs 
to  enter  into  public–private  partnerships.  The  NWSSP  defines  the  roles  and  responsibilities  of 
the  private  sector  as  providing  “RWSS  infrastructure  related  services  to  communities  with 
efficiency, accountability, and in response to community demand.” The same policy emphasizes 
the  importance  that  MRD  delegate  planning  and  direct  implementation  to  PDRDs,  and  so 
concentrate on monitoring and regulation, while at the same time promoting the participation of 
the private sector. 
 
11. 
Improved  community  water  supply  will  not  result  in  full  economic  and  health  benefits 
without  due  attention  to  hygiene  and  sanitation  education.  Very  low  sanitation  awareness  in 
rural  Cambodia  hinders  the  development  of  good  sanitation  practices and  the  improvement  of 
public and household sanitation infrastructure. In rural areas, few people are aware of how good

sanitation improves health. Very few people use latrines, regularly clean water jars, boil drinking 
water,  or  use  soap  when  washing  their  hands.  A  comprehensive  sanitation  awareness 
campaign and the participation of local communities in the design of sanitation solutions must 
accompany or occur prior to the development of sanitation infrastructure. 
 
12. 
Information is lacking about present RWSS coverage in Cambodia, the extent of which 
varies  greatly  according  to  the  source  and  the  indicators  used  in  the  different  surveys  and 
analyses. At least five different sources9 are used to define RWSS coverage. Each source uses 
different  definitions  of  coverage  according  to  the  distance  of  users  from  the  source,  the 
availability of the source throughout the year, and the amount and quality of the water available. 
Setting  up  a  nationwide  RWSS  database  that  uses  uniform  criteria  and  is  accessible  to  all 
stakeholders would allow reliable assessment of RWSS provision in Cambodia. 
 
13.  While MRD has gained substantial knowledge of RWSS since its creation in 1993, much 
of  this  knowledge  rests  with  a  few  qualified  staff,  often  seconded  to  various  externally  funded 
projects. At provincial and district levels, this situation may cause a recurrent lack of capacity to 
implement  projects.  At  the  local  level,  the  commune  councils  that  were  legally  established 
nationwide after the elections of February 2002 require significant time and resources to enable 
them  to  perform  their  delegated  functions.  MRD,  PDRDs,  and  district  offices  of  rural 
development  (DORD)  staff  require  capacity  building,  as  do  village  and  commune  personnel. 
Although  the  NWSSP  and  the  RWSS  Sector  Investment  Plan  (2005–2015)  provide  a 
comprehensive  framework  to  develop  the  sector,  the  preparation  of  an  RWSS  strategy  and 
implementation guidelines are necessary to ensure the appropriate application of the policy and 
investment plan. Establishing a specific strategic unit within MRD is required for this purpose, as 
is a development partners’ forum to support the development of the sector.  
 
14. 
The  poorest  are  often  forgotten  in  the  decision-making  mechanisms  regarding  water 
supply and sanitation and, in many cases, are excluded from service. Several nongovernment 
organization (NGO)-supported projects10 have recently developed, and experimented on a pilot 
basis, sustainable mechanisms to identify and integrate the poorest households. The Project will 
build upon the experiences of these organizations to identify and target the poorest 20% in each 
village. 
 
15. 
Lack  of  access  to  safe  and  reliable  supply  of  drinking  water,  inadequate  sanitation 
facilities,  and  poor  sanitation  awareness  result  in  poor  health  for  rural  people,  lost  productive 
time  due  to  sickness  or  the  need  to  care  for  sick  family  members,  missed  schooling 
opportunities  for  children,  and  increased  medical  expenditures.  Women  (especially  female 
heads of households) and children, primarily bear the responsibility for collecting water and are 
the  worst  affected  by  this  situation.  The  socioeconomic  survey  carried  out  during  project 
preparation  shows  that  water-related  diseases  are  common  among  the  households  surveyed. 
The  most  common  of  them  is  diarrhea,  whose  prevalence  in  most  participating  provinces  is 
higher than the national average.

17. 
The  Project  will  assist  the  Government  in  achieving  its  RWSS  Sector  Investment  Plan 
(2005–2015) national targets of increasing the percentage of the rural population with access to 
safe water to 50%, and of sanitation facilities to 30%, in the provinces of Battambang, Kampong

1,087,000  people  and  access  to  sanitation  to  720,000  people  in  the  rural  areas  in  the 
participating  provinces.  The  Project  will  empower  communities  to  take  responsibility  for 
developing  and  maintaining  RWSS  facilities  according  to  their  needs;  increase  awareness  of 
healthy  and  hygienic  behavior;  and  improve  the  Government’s  capacity  to  facilitate,  regulate

Appendix 4.

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Benefits and Impacts 

51. 
The  Project  will  directly  benefit  an  estimated  1.09  million  people  with  improved  safe 
drinking  water  facilities,  of  which  about  0.72  million  will  also  benefit  from  improved  sanitation 
facilities  in  the  project  area.  The  Project  is  expected  to  realize  its  anticipated  benefits  without 
significant adverse impacts. Limited adverse impacts identified in the analyses were eliminated 
or mitigated in the design of the Project. 
 
Poverty  Reduction  Impacts.  The  five  provinces  have  a  combined  population  of  3.5 
52. 
million  people  in  2005,  of  whom  1.35  million  (39%)  live  below  the  official  poverty  line.  About 
85%  of  the  total  population  in  the  five  provinces  is  rural.  Rural  households,  whose  primary 
source  of  income  comes  from  agriculture,  account  for  almost  90%  of  Cambodia’s  poor.  The 
Project is expected to meet the CMDG targets 7.10 (50% of the rural population to have access 
to safe water) and 7.12 (30% of the rural population to have access to improved sanitation) in 
the five provinces by 2011. About 50–70% of the project beneficiaries are expected to be poor 
given  the  high  proportion  of  poor  engaged  in  agriculture  in  the  project  provinces,  and  the 
targeting of the poorest households and communes in the project area. The provision of RWSS 
options will not discriminate against any communities or households due to ethnicity. 
 
53. 
Gender and Social Impacts. Improved access to safe and reliable water and sanitation 
will  result  in  time  savings,  a  reduced  burden  of  labor,  and  improved  family  health.  Women  in 
particular will benefit from the time savings and improved access to safe water by having more 
time to participate in income-generating activities, and to attend to school. As active members of 
WSUGs  and  WSUG  boards,  women  will  have  equal  opportunities  to  receive  technical  training 
and  RWSS-related  skills  development  under  the  Project.  Better-quality  water  and  access  to 
improved  sanitation  will  also  reduce  the  prevalence  and  severity  of  waterborne  and  water-
related diseases. Hygiene and sanitation education for both men and women will complement 
the RWSS infrastructure. Improved access to infrastructure and better understanding of proper 
hygiene  practices  will  contribute  to  fewer  days  lost  due  to  sickness  and  a  reduction  in  related 

 

  

17

health  expenditures.  The  Project  will  also  contribute  indirectly  to  achieving  CMDG  target  4.1 
(reducing by half the mortality rate among children under the age of 5).  
 
54. 
Environmental  Impacts  and  Benefits.  The  Project  will  have  a  positive  impact  on  the 
local environment of project areas due to improved access to safe drinking water and sewerage 
management  based  on  new  latrines  and  septic  tanks.  The  quantity  of  sewage  and  waste 
disposed of into rivers will reduce. The IEE found that potentially adverse environmental impacts 
are  minor,  temporary,  and  possible  to  mitigate.  An  EARF  has  been  developed  to  guide  the 
environmental assessment and implementation of environmental mitigation, as well as monitor 
environmental conditions during project implementation. 
 
55. 
Community  Empowerment.  The  Project  will  have  a  positive  impact  on  communities’ 
capacity  to  promote  their  own  development.  Their  active  involvement  in  selecting,  planning, 
cofinancing, and implementing project interventions, and their taking responsible for the O&M of 
the  facilities,  will  drive  their  empowerment.  The  communities  will  subsequently  be  able  to  use

WSUGs, (iv) water use and hygiene education to incorporate the water and sanitation needs of 
different ethnic groups, and (v) the inclusion of ethnicity issues in the project guidelines.  
 
57. 
Increased  Government  Capacity  and  Coordination.  MRD  and  the  participating 
PDRDs  and  DORDs  will  improve  their  performance  to  better  plan,  regulate,  and  facilitate  the 
development of the RWSS sector. Provinces, districts, communes, and villages will develop the 
capacity  to  take  new  responsibilities.  The  Project  will  promote  greater  transparency  regarding 
the  provision  of  information  and  decision-making  processes  at  all  administrative  levels.  The 
capacity  of  government  officials  working  in  RWSS  will  be  improved  in  such  areas  as  project 
management  planning  and  administration,  financial  management  and  accounting,  community 
participation  techniques  and  gender  awareness,  data  collection  and  management,  public–
private  partnerships,  environmental  and  resettlement  issues,  and  such  technical  aspects  as 
monitoring  water  quality  and  supervising  drilling  operations.  The  establishment  of  a  strategic 
unit  on  RWSS  and  a  development  partners  forum  will  improve  the  efficiency  of  the  sector  by 
providing  new  opportunities  for  better  flow  of  information  among  all  stakeholders,  increased 
coordination and sharing of good practices and lessons learned.    
 
58. 
Economic Benefits. The economic benefits of the water supply component include both 
cost savings relative to current water use and welfare improvements from increased water use. 
Water supplied by the Project has a lower total economic cost (based on storage costs and time 
spent  in  collection)  than  current  supplies,  so  the  Project  will  reduce  the  resources  that 
households are required to commit to maintain their current, minimal water use. The lower cost 
will  enable  households  to  increase  their  water  consumption,  providing  additional  benefits  that 
would  not  be  available  without  the  Project.  The  economic  analyses  of  sample  subprojects 
confirm that the Project's benefits will exceed its costs. It shows that the proposed investments 
for each village have a strong economic basis, with an economic internal rate of return of 19.5–
23.9%, well above the assumed economic opportunity cost of capital of 12%. As the benefit-cost 
analysis  did  not  include  many  potentially  important  environmental  and  health  benefits,  the 
economic internal rate of return is a conservative estimate of economic benefits in each village.

59. 
Changes  to  the  Decentralization  and  Deconcentration  Processes.  The  Project 
assumes continued Government support for the decentralization and deconcentration policies. 
However, uncertainty exists regarding the modalities and depth of these policies that may affect 
the  responsibilities  of  provincial  or  commune  authorities.  The  Project  has  been  designed  with

60. 
Lack of WSUG Participation and Ownership Negatively Affect the Sustainability of 
the Systems. The social cohesion required within the WSUGs to manage RWSS schemes on a 
sustainable basis is not always present in the rural communities in Cambodia. The community 
mobilization  component  will  support  the  establishment  and  sound  operation  of  the  WSUG  to 
ensure  that  they  mobilize  sufficient  resources  and  are  willing  to  pay  their  O&M  costs.  Each 
WSUG  will  cofinance,  participate  in  the  design  of,  and  take  full  responsibility  for  the  O&M  of 
RWSS facilities to ensure its long-term sustainability. A contribution plan is in Appendix 15. 
 
61. 
Insufficient Availability of Experienced and Efficient NGOs. The key to the effective 
empowering  of  communities  lies  with  NGOs.  However,  experienced  NGOs  are  generally 
expensive  and  in  short  supply  in  Cambodia.  Intensive  training  of  NGOs,  coupled  with  close 
supervision,  monitoring,  and  back-stopping,  will  be  required  to  ensure  quality  control  and 
effective  community  mobilization.  The  Project  has  allocated  sufficient  resources  to  intensively 
train NGOs and supervise their performance.  
 
62. 
Lack of Access to Safe Water Sources. For particular villages, especially those where 
surface and shallow groundwater is of very poor quality due to higher contents of arsenic, iron, 
or other pollutants, or where the water table is very low, finding an appropriate and affordable 
technical solution for RWSS may be difficult. The Project will undertake an initial environmental 
screening for each village before the communities finalize a WSSVP. Pilot groundwater testing 
will be done under the Project for the difficult cases, and new technologies will be tested.

LESSONS LEARNED 

 
1. 
Promote  the  construction  of  water  points  on  private  land  owned  by  a  member  of  the 
water  and  sanitation  user  group  (WSUG).  Community-based  systems  will  not  necessarily 
ensure  sustainability  unless  the  incentives  are  properly  addressed  in  the  project  design  and 
implementation. The impact assessment1 of a rural water supply and sanitation (RWSS) project, 
carried  out  in  130  selected  villages  in  the  poorest  areas  of  six  provinces  of  Cambodia,  found 
that  water  supply  systems  solely  managed  by  a  community  structure  failed  shortly  after  their 
construction.  Except  where  there  are  active  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  rural 
Cambodians rarely act as communities. The above survey also found that the externally driven 
community-based organizations, such as water point committees created to manage the hand 
pumps,  failed  to  perform  their  management  functions  effectively,  despite  a  strong  capacity-
building process in the program, when the water points were placed on public land. In contrast, 
the community systems constructed on private land or managed by a member of the community 
with  a  direct  personal  interest  in  the  management  of  the  system  is  better  maintained  and,  in 
most cases, accessible by all.  
 
2. 
Include a wide range of simple technology options for open choice by communities and 
households.  As  most  wells  will  be  maintained  by  local  people,  technologies  recommended  for 
the systems should be locally appropriate. Direct access and easy availability of spare parts at 
affordable prices should be guaranteed. In certain areas where sparse coverage is due to the 
lack  of  suitable  options  or  equipment,  it  is  necessary  to  test  new  solutions  and  prepare 
packages of civil works contracts that allow the private sector to buy adequate equipment. The 
choice  of  options,  especially  for  deep  pumps,  should  be  open,  and  people  should  decide  the 
type  of  equipment  they  are  ready  to  pay  for.  Type  of  deep  pumps  that  were  promoted  in 
Cambodia,  with  the  aim  of  facilitating  maintenance,  has  had  its  limitations  and  has  not 
generated  the  expected  countrywide  deep-pump  spare-part  network.  The  Project  will  offer  a 
range options with different costs, and water and sanitation user groups (WSUGs) will choose. 
 
3. 
Encourage  private  sector  participation  in  the  management  of  piped  water  systems. 
Whereas  rural  communities  have  difficulties  managing  community  infrastructure  and  collecting 
local  contributions,  rural  Cambodians  are  well  disposed  toward  private  sector  participation. 
There are many successful private sector initiatives in rural water supply (private vendors, small 
piped water systems). In the case of rural piped water systems managed by the private sector,2 
satisfaction  and  payment  rates  are  excellent,  respectively  85%  and  99%.  The  assistance  of 
private  sector  in  managing  community  water  infrastructure  offers  a  chance  to  increase  the 
sustainability of water systems, with appropriate conditions guaranteeing access for the poorest 
residents. The Project will provide training to private sector operators and develop a database of 
companies to facilitate private sector participation. 
 
Stress the importance of operation and maintenance (O&M) of RWSS facilities. Projects 
4. 
and  NGOs  have  provided  free  water  equipment  without  any  consideration  for  the  necessity  of 
covering the cost of O&M, even when people were willing and able to pay. Water infrastructure

5. 
Integrate  water,  sanitation,  and  hygiene  education  in  RWSS  projects.  In  many  cases, 
improving community water supply does not result in full economic and health benefits due to a 
lack of attention to hygiene education and sanitation. The very low level of sanitation awareness 
in rural Cambodia hinders the development of good sanitation practices and the improvement of 
public  and  household  sanitation  infrastructure.  In  rural  areas,  few  people  are  aware  of  the 
relationship  between  good  sanitation  practices  and  improved  health.  Very  few  people  use 
latrines, regularly clean water jars, boil drinking water, or use soap when washing their hands. 
The  Project  will  implement  a  national  campaign  that  aims  to  change  hygiene  behavior  with 
practical  information  and  demonstrations.  The  Project  will  include  a  comprehensive  sanitation 
awareness  campaign  in  the  participating  provinces,  to  take  place  before  or  during  the 
development of sanitation infrastructure. 
 
6. 
Encourage  the  deconcentration  and  decentralization  of  decision  making.  International 
experience  shows  that  planning  and  managing  RWSS  is  better  done  by  local  authorities  and 
communities, with the central Government taking the role or regulator and policy developer. The 
Project  will  promote  the  current  decentralization  process,  which  gives  more  power  to  the 
communes to decide their priorities and enter into contracts directly with NGOs and the private 
sector.  The  selection  of  projects  will  be  done,  in  principle,  through  the  current  commune 
planning  process.  The  Project  will  also  promote  deconcentration  from  the  center  to  the 
provinces. Planning and supervision of project implementation will be done provincially.  
 
7. 
Place  the  community  at  the  forefront  of  decision  making  and  management  and 
encourage  community  contributions.  The  participation  of  communities  is  a  key  condition  for 
sustainable RWSS systems. The Project will place villages and commune councils at the center 
of  the  decision-making  process  regarding  the  selection,  preparation,  and  implementation  of 
subprojects.  The  Project  will  help  villages  and  commune  councils  understand  and  actively 
participate in all the phases of the project cycle. WSUGs will contribute 10% of the capital cost 
of water supply infrastructure and about 50% of the capital cost of sanitation facilities. Villages 
and communes will prepare and approve village water and sanitation plans with the assistance 
of NGOs. To improve the transparency of the process, special procedures will be put in place to 
receive and deal with complaints from local individuals openly and fairly. 
 
8. 
Recognize women as the primary users of water, hygiene educators, and managers of 
RWSS  systems,  and  involve  women  in  their  development  and  O&M.  Although  women’s 
priorities are often tied to the provision of water supply and private latrines, their formal role in 
RWSS  remains  limited.  The  Project  will  mainstream  gender  at  the  institutional  level  and 
enhance women’s role in daily decision making and technical skills development. It will build the 
capacity  of  the  gender  working  group  within  the  Ministry  of  Rural  Development  by  developing 
national  guidelines  for  gender  mainstreaming  in  RWSS.  The  Project  will  encourage  the  equal 
participation and representation of women in formal decision-making units at all administrative 
levels. As discussions with school officials reveal that girls, especially adolescent girls, are often 
shy  to  use  the  same  block  of  latrine  facilities  as  boys,  the  Project  will  construct  and  locate 
separate school latrines that are clearly marked for girls.  
 
9. 
Develop  partnerships  and  information  sharing  among  all  stakeholders  to  benefit  the 
RWSS  sector.  Several  pilot  projects  involving  local  partnerships  between  communes,  NGOs, 
and  the  private  sector  have  improved  RWSS  sustainability.  Nationally,  the  organization  of 
workshops  between  the  different  government  ministries,  NGOs,  and  development  partners  for 
the preparation of the NWSSP has been very beneficial to the sector. The Project will promote 
the establishment of partnerships nationally and locally.

Cambodia had a total population of 13 million in 2004, with an annual population growth rate of 1.8%. The country’s 
gross domestic product (GDP) grew at an average rate of 5.2% in 2003, with a GDP per capita of $296. The highest 
growth was seen in agriculture. About 84% of the population resides in rural areas, with a population density of 268 
persons per km2 of arable land. The Tonle Sap basin covers about 44% of Cambodia's total area and has about one 
third of the country’s total population. During 1993–1999, Cambodia experienced a slight reduction in poverty from 
39% to 36%. c  The poverty rate is estimated at 29.7% in urban areas and at 40.1% in rural areas. Rural households 
(i.e., those whose primary source of income is agriculture) account for almost 90% of the total poor. The net primary 
school  enrollment  rate  increased  from  76%  in  1997  to  91%  in  2003.  Under-5  child  mortality  remained  at  120  per 
1,000 live births. From 1995 to 2000, maternal mortality fell from 590 to 437 per 100,000 live births. 
 
Cambodia has one of the lowest levels of water and sanitation coverage in southeast Asia. According to the RWSS 
Sector Investment Plan (SIP, 2005–2015), an estimated 31.7% of the rural population has access to safe water, and 
12.5% to sanitation. The development of RWSS improves the health of the rural people by reducing the incidence of 
water-related diseases and the associated costs of health care and treatment. RWSS contributes to the economic 
productivity of men and women, especially in terms of time savings, and it reduces burden of labor. It also provides 
opportunities for private sector participation in the development of rural infrastructure and generates employment in 
rural communities for construction, operation and maintenance. 
 
The Project is expected to meet the CMDGs in the five provinces by providing, by 2011, safe water to 1.09 million 
rural  people  and  latrine  access  to  0.72  million  rural  people.  The  current  rural  population  in  the  five  provinces  is 
estimated to  be 2.96 million in 2005 and expected to reach 3.36 million  by 2011. The  Project  will rehabilitate  and 
upgrade existing  water supply  and sanitation infrastructure and provide capital for  new  community  and household 
infrastructure.  Family  water  supply  systems  will  be  provided  when  community  options  are  not  possible.  Project 
components  include  (i)  community  mobilization  and  skills  development,  (ii)  development  of  water  supply  systems; 
(iii)  development  of  sanitation  facilities;  and  (iv)  capacity  building  and  implementation  support.  The  water  use  and 
hygiene education program will learn from past campaigns and coordinate with ongoing efforts.  
 
The five provinces were selected on the basis of their low RWSS coverage, high poverty rate, and population size, 
as  well  as  a  regional  focus.  The  poor  are  targeted  in  three  ways:  (i)  at  the  macro  level,  provinces  have  been 
selected based on high poverty incidence; (ii) at the meso level, the subproject pre-selection criteria will give priority 
to villages found in the poorest 20% of communes in each province; and (iii) at the micro level, villagers will identify

they can afford, as sanitation options are subsidized based on technology.

Background 

 
1. 
The Tonle Sap Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Project (the Project) provides 
significant  benefits  to  rural  residents  in  the  five  Cambodian  provinces  of  Battambang, 
Kampong  Chhnang,  Kampong  Thom,  Pursat,  and  Siem  Reap.  The  Project  is  expected  to 
provide, by 2001, safe water to 1.09 million rural people and latrine access to 0.72 million rural 
people.  A  gender  action  plan  (GAP)  has  been  prepared  to  highlight  the  different  rural  water 
supply and sanitation (RWSS) needs of men and women in Cambodia. It also helps to ensure 
that  both  men  and  women  have  equal  opportunities  for  employment  and  to  participate  in 
training  at  all  levels.  The  GAP  is  based  on  gender  analysis  prepared  for  the  Project,  and  is 
designed according to ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development. 
 
A. 
 
2. 
Females make up 51.5% of the total population in the project area. About 85% of the 
total population resides in rural areas. The male:female ratio is estimated at 94:100 in 2005. 
Life  expectancy  in  the  project  provinces  is  62  years  for  women  and  56  years  for  men,  both 
figures  lower  than  the  national  average  of  64  for  women  and  58  for  men.  In  1998,  the 
percentage of female-headed households (FHHs) was higher in four of the project area’s five 
provinces than the national average of about 26%, ranging from 27% in Kampong Chhnang to 
29% in Battambang. Pursat was the exception with 24%. Categories of FHHs often identified 
by  commune  council  leaders  include  those  headed  by  (i)  widows,  (ii)  divorcees,  (iii) women 
whose  husbands  do  not  contribute  to  household  management;  and  (iv)  women  whose 
husbands  are  absent  migrant  workers.  The  high  percentage  of  widows  is  a  consequence  of 
Cambodia’s historical political conflict.  Most female household heads are aged 40 and older.  
 
3. 
Gender  analysis  is  intricately  linked  with  issues  of  ethnicity  and  poverty.  The  Khmer 
majority has a matrifocal bias, in which (i) newly married couples live in the brides’ households 
during the first few years and (ii) daughters inherit household assets, including land, on equal 
terms as sons. Age plays an important role in that the youngest offspring often receives more 
property  than  older  children.  However,  women  customarily  cede  the  responsibility  of  signing 
documents and title papers to men because these are public and official functions. The Cham 
minority follow Muslim norms where inheritance is divided 2:1 in favor of sons over daughters. 
The Vietnamese follow a custom that provides equal inheritance for both sons and daughters. 
The Chinese generally practice a patrifocal system, where brides live with their in-laws.  
 
B. 
 
Men and women are responsible for different types of work that define their social roles. 
4. 
Women  engage  in  productive  work,  household  activities,  and  family  care.  Demands  on  their 
time  and  a  lack  of  access  to  resources  hinders  their  ability  to  participate  in  household  and 
community decisions. Women’s priorities are often associated with the provision of water and 
private  latrines.  The  socioeconomic  surveys  found  75%  of  respondents  reported  that  the 
burden of collecting water falls on women and children. Findings revealed that men and boys 
also collect water,  especially  during  the  dry  season  when  water  sources  are  remote.  Limited 
access  to  potable  water  in  the  dry  season  significantly  affects  the  living  conditions  of  poor 
households  and  FHHs.  Discussions  with  women  in  Kampong  Chhnang  and  Kampong  Thom 
indicated that, in the dry season, women and children spend up to 3 hours per day collecting 
water due to the remoteness of the source, the need for frequent trips, or long queues at water

Alignment with country’s development strategies. Rural water supply and sanitation

good governance. Provision of RWSS facilities is highlighted as one means to achieve inclusive 
social development, and the RWSS sector is identified as one in which ADB will play a catalytic 
role.  The  CSP  also  stresses  three  crosscutting  themes—private  sector  development,  gender,

crosscutting  themes.  The  Tonle  Sap  basin  is  identified  as  the  priority  area  where  ADB

sanitation  as  one  of  the  two  sectors  for  grant  financing,  together  with  the  control  of

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

Introduction 

 
A. 
 
This appendix demonstrates the economic justification for small-scale water supply and 
1. 
sanitation investments in rural Cambodia, using as case studies three villages in the provinces 
of Kompong Thom and Pursat: Trapeang Chouk, Thnot, and Steung Leu. The proposed Tonle 
Sap  Rural  Supply  Water  and  Sanitation  Sector  Project  (the  Project)  will  ultimately  include 
hundreds of similar small-scale investments in other villages. The different types of investments 
will  be  determined  through  a  participatory  process  of  informed  choice  during  project 
implementation.  As  such,  a  complete  economic  analysis  of  the  Project  as  a  whole  is  not 
possible  at  this  stage.  In  addition  to  demonstrating  the  economic  justification  of  such 
investments,  the  economic  analysis  provides  a  model  and  guidelines  for  further  economic 
analysis and selection of additional investments. 
 

Rationale for Government Involvement, and the Role of Private Sector 

B. 
 
2. 
The economic rationale for Government involvement in rural water supply and sanitation 
is  based  largely  on  poverty  reduction.  In  theory,  the  private  sector  should  be  able  to  develop 
and supply water and sanitation services, and private investment has in fact occurred in some 
villages. The main obstacles to widespread private investment are the dispersed, diffused and 
diverse  nature  of  the  market,  the  lack  of  an  efficient  private  sector,  and  the  low  income  of 
potential consumers. 
 
The main quantifiable benefits of the water supply component are reductions in the cost 
3. 
of buying and conveying water to private homes, and of medical expenses, and increases in the 
time available for education, generation income, and recreation. These benefits will be realized 
by  improving  or  developing  new  permanent  water  sources  close  to  people's  homes.  As  the 
population density of rural Cambodia is quite low, developing rural water supply requires many 
very  small  investments,  each  investment  serving  few  people.  The  low  income  of  the  people 
served  means  that  they  are  neither  willing  nor  able  to  pay  enough  for  water  and  sanitation 
services to generate sufficient profits to attract private investors. 
 
4. 
As part of its water supply and sanitation policy, the Government therefore intervenes to 
provide most of the initial capital investment to develop rural water supply and sanitation. Water 
and  sanitation  user  groups  (WSUGs)  will  manage  the  facilities  from  the  outset  and  be 
responsible for all operating and maintenance (O&M) costs. In all cases, a user contribution will 
be  required  to  sustain  the  facility  and  cover  O&M  costs.  The  Project  expects  and  encourages 
the  development  of  a  private  market  for  managing  water  supply  facilities  and  that,  when 
necessary,  villages  will  contract  individuals  or  small  private  firms  to  help  them  to  maintain  the 
facilities.

1. 
The  purpose  of  requiring  contributions  from  the  community  for  rural  water  supply  and 
sanitation  (RWSS),  as  in  the  proposed  Tonle  Sap  Rural  Supply  Water  and  Sanitation  Sector 
Project (the Project), is to ensure ownership and sustainability of the infrastructure provided by 
the  Project.  Community  contribution  toward  capital  cost  is  often  used  to  measure  community 
ownership. Discussions with villagers about their contribution often revolve around payment for 
the cost of construction and rarely focus on operation and maintenance (O&M) costs. However, 
initial  contributions  for  the  construction  of  facilities  do  not  guarantee  that  users  will  be  able  to 
operate  and  maintain  them.  A  water  and  sanitation  user  group  (WSUG)  will  be  established 
under the project for each water point and will include households within a 150-meter catchment 
radius.  WSUGs  are  not  usually  homogenous.  Differences  between  the  better-off  and  the 
poorest households warrant special consideration, as the Project risks marginalizing the poorest 
households  and  vulnerable  groups.  The  poorest  20%  will  be  exempted  from  making  cash 
contributions.  Identification  of  the  poorest  20%  of  households  within  a  village—and  of  other 
vulnerable  households  including  ethnic  minority or  indigenous  groups  and  households  headed

sanitation  village  plans.  The  identification  of  the  poorest  will  be  verified  by  the  village  chief, 
commune  council,  and  participating  nongovernment  organization  (NGO).  This  is  imperative  to
